definitions.definition: an object in the shape of a circle, usually made of gold and precious stones, that a king or queen wears on his or her head on official occasions

examples.text: The crown was placed upon the new monarch's head.
the emperor's jewel-encrusted crown

definitions.definition: the government of a country, thought of as being represented by a king or queen

examples.text: land owned by the Crown
a Minister of the Crown
Who's appearing for the Crown *(= bringing a criminal charge against somebody on behalf of the state)* in this case?
a piece of Crown land

definitions.definition: the position or power of a king or queen

examples.text: She refused the crown *(= refused to become queen)*.
his claim to the French crown
He succeeded to the crown of Spain.
In 1553 the crown passed from Edward VI to Mary.
In 1688 the crown was offered to William and Mary.

definitions.definition: a circle of flowers, leaves, etc. that is worn on somebody’s head, sometimes as a sign of victory
the position of winning a sports competition

examples.text: She is determined to retain her Wimbledon crown.
He lost his world crown to the Korean champion.
He won the final race of the season to clinch the world crown.

definitions.definition: the top part of the head or a hat

examples.text: There were raindrops on his bald crown.
She swept her hair into a bun on the crown of her head.
the crown of a hill
from the crown of the final bend

definitions.definition: the part of a plant just above and below the ground

examples.text: Roses bloom on shoots that sprout from the crown of the mother plant.

definitions.definition: the top of a tree or other plant

examples.text: Nests were built high in the crowns of trees.

definitions.definition: an artificial cover for a damaged tooth
the part of the tooth that is above the gum
anything in the shape of a crown, especially as a decoration or a badge
a unit of money in several European countries

examples.text: Czech crowns

definitions.definition: an old British coin worth five shillings (= now 25p)
the most attractive or valuable part of something

examples.text: The Knightsbridge branch is the jewel in the crown of a 500-strong chain of stores.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French corune (noun), coruner (verb), Old French corone (noun), coroner (verb), from Latin corona ‘wreath, chaplet’.
